chapter.title: Getting Started
chapter.para: Here, you may put some introductory stuff. I'm going to lay this chapter out just so you can see some of the docbook basics. Don't assume that I care about the organization I've laid out. Rearrange as you see fit, but pay attention to the naming conventions on things with an "id". These serve two purposes. They are targets for links. Since there are hundreds of them in this manual, following conventions is important. Also, when creating "chunked" HTML, they serve as the basis for the file names. As we start to integrate the manual into the UI, keeping consistent filenames will be important (otherwise, docbook generates mangled names for sections).

Anyway, here are some basic markups you may want. When referring to a constant (such as an option in the UI) use this type of markup. You can also draw attention to something with this element. Later on, I'll present a figure. Note that with docbook (and any writing), never refer to the physical location of diagrams/figures. When I wrote a book a few years back, our editor used to yell at us when we wrote things like ...in the figure below... as you're never sure where the figure will end-up in the final rendering. It may be on the next page, it may be to the left, etc. That is determined by the stylesheet. Instead, you can use an "xref" tag. The nifty thing about the "xref" tags is that they not only create a hyperlink (in html), but also substitute the "title" of the thing being referred to for the xref. For example, I may say refer to . If you look at the source, you do not see the title of the referrant, yet it is in the final product.
We'll spell check this thing at the end. I'm a terrible speller. btw: this is also an example of an "admonition" - which is like a little "asside". You can use "note", "warning", "important", "caution", and "tip". Nifty little icons are next to these admonitions.
